name: Welcome
contraceptive-intro
response:
text:🛡️ Contraceptives
Before we talk about contraceptives, let's clarify some things-;
text:❓ What is unplanned pregnancy?
👉 An unplanned pregnancy is a pregnancy that occurs earlier than desired.
👉 Contraception is the act of preventing pregnancy.
👉 Contraceptives can be a device, medication, procedure, or behavior.;
text:To better understand, select an option-
1️⃣ How to do a pregnancy test
2️⃣ Choosing a contraceptive

name: pregnancy-test
response:
text:🧪 How to Do a Pregnancy Test
Here’s a summary of the three common methods for taking a pregnancy test;

text:a. 🩸 Use a dropper
👉 Collect urine in a clean cup.
👉 Use a dropper to place a few drops onto the test strip or into the test well.

b. 🚿 Direct on urine stream
👉 Hold the test strip directly in your urine stream while you pee.
👉 Follow the test kit instructions carefully.

c. 🌡️ Dip the test strip
👉 Collect urine in a clean cup.
👉 Dip the test strip into the urine for the specified time mentioned in the test kit instructions.

👉 Enter 1 for information on abortion.

name: choosing-contraceptives
response:
text:Choosing the Right Contraceptive
Choosing the right contraceptive method depends on various factors, including your health, lifestyle, and personal preferences. There are different types of contraceptives available for both men and women.;
text:Select an option to learn more-
1️⃣ For women
2️⃣ For men
3️⃣ For adolescents

name: adolescents-contraceptives
response:
text:3️⃣ Contraceptives for Adolescents
Yes! Most contraceptive methods are safe for adolescents. Recommended options include-

💊 Pills
💉 Injectables
🛡️ Condoms

Adolescents can also access contraceptives confidentially at youth-friendly centers.

name: women-contraceptive-options
response:
text:👩‍🦰 Women’s Contraceptives
There are two main types of contraceptives for women-

1️⃣ Non-hormonal contraceptives
2️⃣ Hormonal contraceptives

👉 Choose an option to learn more!

name: abortion-intro
response:
text:⚕️ Safe Abortion
A safe abortion is a medically recommended procedure by the WHO to end a pregnancy. It is performed by trained healthcare professionals to ensure the health and safety of the individual.

There are two main types of safe abortion-
1️⃣ Medication abortion
2️⃣ Surgical abortion

👉 Enter the option number to learn more.

name: medication-abortion
response:
text:Medication Abortion

According to the World Health Organization (WHO), a medication abortion (also known as medical abortion) involves the use of pharmacological drugs to terminate a pregnancy. This method is typically used within the first 12 weeks of pregnancy and can be safely self-managed by an individual outside of a healthcare facility, provided they have access to accurate information, quality medicines, and support from a trained health worker.;
text:To learn more about medical abortion, click the link below. A medication abortion involves taking two pills, and it works best if done within 12 weeks of pregnancy-

Mifepristone- It stops the pregnancy from growing.
Misoprostol- It helps expel the pregnancy from the body.;
text:🚀 Enter the corresponding option number to know more-

1-💊 How to take Mifepristone and Misoprostol
2-👀 Signs after taking the pills
3-⚠️ Warning signs after taking the pills
4-🏥 Where you can get the pills
5-👶 If you can have children after a medical abortion
6-💬 Talk to a counselor

name: surgical-abortion
response:
text:🩺 Surgical Abortion
A surgical abortion is a medical procedure used to terminate a pregnancy by removing the contents of the uterus through a minor surgical process.

To learn more, choose an option-
1️⃣ Dilation and Evacuation
2️⃣ Manual Vacuum Aspiration

👉 Enter the option number to continue.

name: taking-miso-mife
signs-after-pills
response:
text:👀 Signs after taking the pills-
You may experience cramps, bleeding (which can last from a few days to 3 weeks, depending on your system and the age of the pregnancy) similar to a heavy period and nausea.
It is important to follow instructions carefully to ensure safety.
To continue, enter-
1️⃣ For more information on medication abortion
2️⃣ For information on surgical abortion

name: warning-signs-pills
response:
text:⚠️ Warning signs after taking the pills-

Heavy Bleeding – Soaking through two or more sanitary pads per hour

Severe Pain – Intense abdominal or pelvic pain not relieved by medication

Fever – A fever of 100.4°F (38°C) or higher lasting more than 24 hours

Nausea, Vomiting, or Diarrhea – These symptoms lasting more than 24 hours
Foul-Smelling Discharge – Any unusual or foul-smelling vaginal discharge

name: getting-pills
response:
text:🏥 Where You Can Get the Pills
You can access abortion pills through-
Trusted clinics, healthcare providers, and pharmacies with the help of AUNTY QUEEN
Hotline through a counselor, who provides safe abortion information and support.;
text:📞 Need help? Contact the AUNTY QUEEN hotline for guidance and support.

👉 Enter 1 for information on abortion.
👉 Enter 2 to explore contraceptives.

name: having-children-after-abortion
response:
text:👶 Can You Have Children After a Medical Abortion?
Yes! A safe and correctly performed medical abortion does not affect your ability to have children in the future. Your fertility remains unaffected.

👉 Enter 1 to learn more about when to start having sex after a medical abortion.

name: when-to-start-having-sex
response:
text:🛑 When Can You Start Having Sex After a Medical Abortion?
You can start having sex when you feel ready. To avoid another unplanned pregnancy, it’s important to use contraceptives.;
text:💊 Contraceptives After Abortion
Here’s how soon you can start using contraceptives after a medical abortion-

Pills, Shot, Patch, Implant - Can be used immediately or within 5 days for immediate protection. If started more than 5 days after taking Misoprostol, wait 7 days for effectiveness.

IUD (Intrauterine Device) -

Copper IUD - Effective immediately if inserted after the abortion is confirmed.

Hormonal IUD - If inserted within 7 days of the abortion, it’s effective immediately. If inserted more than 7 days after, wait 7 days for effectiveness.

👉 Enter 1 for more information on medication abortion.
👉 Enter 2 for information on surgical abortion.
👉 Enter 3 for information on contraceptives.

name: dilation-evacuation
response:
text:🩺 Dilation and Evacuation (D&E)
D&E is a surgical procedure used to terminate a pregnancy during the later stages. It involves dilating the cervix and removing tissue from the uterus.

The procedure is quick, typically taking 10-15 minutes.

You may experience mild discomfort, but pain management options are available to ensure your comfort.

👉 Enter 1 to explore other abortion options.
👉 Enter 2 to end the conversation.

name: MVA
response:
text:🩺 Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA)
MVA is a surgical procedure that uses gentle suction to remove pregnancy tissue. It is recommended for pregnancies up to 12-14 weeks.

The procedure is quick, typically completed within 10-15 minutes.

You may feel mild discomfort, but pain management options are available to ensure your comfort.

👉 Enter 1 to explore other abortion options.
👉 Enter 2 to end the conversation.

name: hormonal-contraceptives
response:
text:💊 Hormonal Contraceptives

Hormonal contraceptives are birth control methods that use hormones (estrogen and progesterone, or just progesterone) to prevent pregnancy. Below are the various types available for women-

1️⃣ Oral Pills
2️⃣ Injectables
3️⃣ IUD (Intrauterine Device)
4️⃣ Implants

👉 Does one of these interest you? Enter the option number to learn more!

name: non-hormonal-contraceptives
response:
text:🛡️ Non-Hormonal Contraceptives

Non-hormonal contraceptives are birth control methods that prevent pregnancy without affecting a woman's hormones. Here are the options available-

1️⃣ Permanent Method (e.g., Tubal Ligation)
2️⃣ Copper IUD
3️⃣ Natural Methods (e.g., Fertility Awareness)
4️⃣ Female Condom
5️⃣ Diaphragm
6️⃣ Spermicides

👉 Does one of these interest you? Enter the option number to learn more!

name: men-contraceptive-options
response:
text:🛡️ Contraceptives for Men

Here are the contraceptive options available for men-

1️⃣ Condom – A barrier method that prevents pregnancy and protects against STIs.
2️⃣ Vasectomy – A permanent surgical procedure for birth control.
3️⃣ Withdrawal Method – Involves withdrawing the penis before ejaculation (less effective).

👉 Does one of these interest you? Enter the option number to learn more!

name: condom-male
response:
text:🛡️ Condom
A condom is a barrier method worn on the penis during intercourse to prevent pregnancy and protect against sexually transmitted infections (STIs). It is widely available over-the-counter at pharmacies and clinics.

👉 Enter 1 to learn more about condoms.

name: vasectomy
response:
text:✂️ Vasectomy

A vasectomy is a permanent surgical procedure that prevents sperm from entering semen, making it highly effective for birth control. It is only recommended if you are certain about not wanting children in the future.

👉 Enter 1 for information on other male contraceptives.
👉 Enter 2 to end the conversation.

name: withdrawal
response:
text:⚠️ Withdrawal Method

The withdrawal method involves pulling out the penis before ejaculation to prevent pregnancy. However, it is less effective because some sperm may still be released before ejaculation.

👉 Enter 1 for information on other male contraceptives.
👉 Enter 2 to end the conversation.

name: condom-indepth
response:
text:🛡️ Condoms – Effectiveness and How They Work
Condoms are 85% effective with typical use (male condoms).

How It Works-
Condoms prevent sperm from entering the uterus, providing both contraception and protection against sexually transmitted infections (STIs).

👉 Enter 1 to learn more about its advantages.
👉 Enter 2 to learn about its limitations.

name: condom-advantages
response:
text:✅ Advantages of Condoms

No side effects - Safe and hormone-free.

Easily available - Accessible over-the-counter at pharmacies and clinics.

Protects against infections - Reduces the risk of STIs, including HIV.

👉 Enter 1 to learn about its limitations
👉 Enter 2 to learn about other male contraceptives.
👉 Enter 2 to end the conversation.

name: condom-limitations
response:
text:⚠️ Limitations of Condoms – What to Do If a Condom Breaks
No need to panic! If your condom bursts, here’s what you can do-

1️⃣ Emergency Contraceptive Pill - Take it as soon as possible (within 72 hours) to prevent pregnancy.
2️⃣ STI Protection - If you’re worried about infections, visit a clinic to ask about post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) for HIV prevention.
3️⃣ STI Testing - Consider getting tested for STIs in 2-3 weeks.

name: birth-control-pills
response:
text:💊 Birth Control Pills (Oral Contraceptives)
Birth control pills are 91% effective with typical use and 99% effective with perfect use.

1️⃣ Combined Pills and How to Use Them
2️⃣ Progesterone-Only Pills and How to Use Them
3️⃣ Possible Side Effects
4️⃣ Warnings
5️⃣ Can Breastfeeding Women Use Them?

name: intrauterine-device
response:
text:🛡️ Intrauterine Device (IUD) – 99% effective.

Hormonal IUD-

Effective for 3-5 years.

How It Works - Releases small amounts of progestin to prevent ovulation and thicken cervical mucus.

Possible Side Effects-

Cramping after insertion.

Irregular periods (with copper IUD).

Spotting.

👉 Enter 1 to learn about other contraceptives.
👉 Enter 2 to end the conversation.

name: injectables
response:
text:💉 Injectables (e.g., Depo-Provera) – 94% effective with typical use.

How It Works-

A hormone injection is administered every 3 months to prevent ovulation.

Advantages-

Long-lasting contraception.

Reduces menstrual pain.

Side Effects-

Weight gain.

Irregular bleeding.

Delay in the return of fertility after stopping use.

👉 Enter 1 to learn about other contraceptives.
👉 Enter 2 to end the conversation.

name: implants
response:
text:💫 Implants (e.g., Nexplanon, Jadelle) – 99% effective.

How It Works-

A small rod is inserted under the skin of the arm, releasing hormones to prevent ovulation for 3-5 years.

Advantages-

Highly effective.

Requires minimal maintenance (no daily or monthly effort).

Possible Side Effects-

Weight changes.

Irregular bleeding.

Mood changes.

👉 Enter 1 to learn about other contraceptives.
👉 Enter 2 to end the conversation.

name: combined-pills
response:
text:💊 Combined Pills
Combined pills contain estrogen and progestin. They are taken daily for 21 days, followed by 7 days of inactive pills (or no pills).

How It Works-

Prevents ovulation.

Thickens cervical mucus to block sperm.

👉 Enter 1 to learn about other contraceptives.
👉 Enter 2 to end the conversation.

name: hormonal-pills-side-effects
response:
text:⚠️ Possible Side Effects of Combined Pills-

Nausea.

Weight gain.

Mood swings.

Spotting.

Missed Pill Management-

If you miss 1 pill, take it as soon as you remember and continue as normal.

If you miss 2 or more pills, take the most recent missed pill immediately, skip any others, and use backup contraception (e.g., condoms) for the next 7 days.

👉 Enter 1 to learn about other contraceptives.
👉 Enter 2 to end the conversation.

name: progesterone-only-pills
response:
text:💊 Progesterone-Only Pills (Mini-Pills)

Prevents ovulation and thickens cervical mucus to block sperm.

Must be taken every day at the same time without a break.

Emergency Contraception (EC) Options-
1️⃣ EC Pills – Levonorgestrel (Plan B) - Effective up to 72 hours after intercourse.
2️⃣ Ulipristal Acetate (EllaOne) - Effective up to 120 hours (5 days) after intercourse.
3️⃣ Copper IUD - Can be inserted up to 5 days after unprotected intercourse for emergency contraception.;
text:Note

EC pills do not cause abortion and are safe to use in emergencies.

They are not a regular contraceptive method and should not replace ongoing birth control.

👉 Enter 1 to learn about other contraceptives.
👉 Enter 2 to end the conversation.

name: hormonal-pills-warnings
response:
text:⚠️ Warnings for Birth Control Pills-

If You Miss One Pill-

Take it as soon as you remember, even if it means taking two pills in one day.

Continue taking the rest of the pills as scheduled.

If You Miss Two or More Pills-

Take the most recent missed pill immediately.

Use condoms or backup contraception for the next 7 days.

Check if emergency contraception is needed if you had unprotected sex during this time.

👉 Enter 1 to learn about other contraceptives.
👉 Enter 2 to end the conversation.

name: breastfeeding-and-pills
response:
text:👶 Contraceptives for Breastfeeding Women
Yes! Progestin-only methods are safe for breastfeeding women and do not affect milk production. These include-

Mini-Pills (Progesterone-Only Pills).

Implants.

Injectables (e.g., Depo-Provera).

Hormonal IUDs.

👉 Enter 2 to end the conversation.

name: permanent-contraceptives
response:
text:✂️ Permanent Contraceptives
For individuals who are certain they do not want any more children.

Female Sterilization (Tubal Ligation)-

Involves blocking or cutting the fallopian tubes to prevent eggs from reaching the uterus.

name: IUD
response:
text:🛡️ Intrauterine Device (IUD) – 99% effective.

Copper IUD-

Effective for up to 10 years.

Prevents fertilization by releasing copper, which is toxic to sperm.

Possible Side Effects-

Cramping after insertion.

Irregular periods (with copper IUD).

Spotting.

name: diaphragm
response:
text:🛡️ Diaphragm

A diaphragm is a non-hormonal contraceptive. It is a shallow, dome-shaped cup made of soft silicone that you insert into your vagina to cover the cervix, preventing sperm from entering the uterus.

name: spermicides
response:
text:🛡️ Spermicides

Spermicides are contraceptive substances that prevent pregnancy by stopping sperm from reaching an egg. They are inserted into the vagina before intercourse and come in various forms, such as-

Gels.

Creams.

Foams.
